conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, use the p-T graph.
From the p-T graph, at 200 K, the pressure is 0.5 x 10^5 Pa; at 400 K, the pressure is 1.0 x 10^5 Pa.
The graph shows a linear relationship between pressure (p) and temperature (T).
Calculate the slope using points (200 K, 0.5 x 10^5 Pa) and (400 K, 1.0 x 10^5 Pa).
Formulate the equation of the line: p = mT + c.
Using point (200 K, 0.5 x 10^5 Pa) to find c: c = 0.
Calculate the pressure at 600 K using p = 0.25 x 10^5 Pa/K * 600 K.
Final answer: The pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is 1.25 x 10^5 Pa.
Note: Calculation error in final step; correct calculation should yield 1.5 x 10^5 Pa.
